question: Where were the first farmers that came to Britain from?
tip: The first farmers arrived in Britain about 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe.

question: Which TWO scientists led a team which was the first to clone an animal?
tip: In 1996, two British scientists, Sir Ian Wilmot (1944–) and Keith Campbell (1954–2012), led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly the sheep. This has led to further research into the possible use of cloning to preserve endangered species and for medical purposes.

question: It is a civil offence to carry a weapon
tip: It is a criminal offence to carry a weapon

question: Where is the Cenotaph located?
tip: At 11.00 am there is a two-minute silence and wreaths are laid at the Cenotaph in Whitehall, London.

question: What was the population of the UK in 1801?
tip: The population of the UK was just 8 million in 1801.

question: When did the first Christian communities begin to appear in Britain?
tip: It was during the 3rd and 4th centuries AD that the first Christian communities began to appear in Britain.

question: The Battle of Somme resulted in how many British causalities on the first day?
tip: One battle, the British attack on the Somme in July 1916, resulted in about 60,000 British casualties on the first day alone.

question: D-Day is the day when the British evacuated the French from Normandy
tip: On 6 June 1944, allied forces landed in Normandy (this event is often referred to as ‘D-Day’).

question: What are the 40 days before Easter known as?
tip: The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent. It is a time when Christians take time to reflect and prepare for Easter. Traditionally, people would fast during this period and today many people will give something up, like a favourite food. The day before Lent starts is called Shrove Tuesday, or Pancake Day. Lent begins on Ash Wednesday.

question: Which TWO words appear in the first two lines of the national anthem ‘God save the Queen’?
tip: The first verse is:‘God save our gracious Queen! Long live our noble Queen! God save the Queen! Send her victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us, God save the Queen!’

question: Which TWO are used when making Haggis?
tip: Scottish Traditional Food: Haggis – a sheep’s stomach stuffed with offal, suet, onions and oatmeal.

question: What were the refugees that came from France between 1680 and 1720 called?
tip: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.

question: When did the English civil war begin?
tip: Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

question: Which TWO are compulsory in the UK if you own an old car?
tip: It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than three years old or without car insurance.

question: Where can you find a solicitor in the UK?
options: Paying expensive Law firms to find one
Go to one of the Youth Courts
tip: Solicitors are trained lawyers who give advice on legal matters. They take action for their clients and represent them in court. The Citizens Advice Bureau can give you names of local solicitors and which areas of law they specialise in. You can also get this information from the Law Society.

question: How old do you have to be to go into betting shops or gambling clubs?
tip: You have to be 18 to go into betting shops or gambling clubs.

question: When was The First British Prime minister (Sir Robert Walpole) in power?
tip: The first man to be called ‘Prime Minister’ was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

question: Who was Isambard Kingdom Brunel?
tip: Brunel was originally from Portsmouth, England. He was an engineer who built tunnels, bridges, railway lines and ships.

question: Who is considered ineligible to do jury service?
tip: Everyone who is summoned to do jury service must do it unless they are not eligible (for example, because they have a criminal conviction) or they provide a good reason to be excused, such as ill health.

question: What kind of event is The Wimbledon Championship?
tip: Tennis evolved in England in the late 19th century. The first tennis club was founded in Leamington Spa in 1872. The most famous tournament hosted in Britain is The Wimbledon Championships, which takes place each year at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club. It is the oldest tennis tournament in the world and the only ‘Grand Slam’ event played on grass.

question: Beefeaters, who tell visitors about the building’s history are associated with which of these?
tip: The Tower of London was first built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066. Tours are given by the Yeoman Warders, also known as Beefeaters, who tell visitors about the building’s history. People can also see the Crown Jewels there.

question: The Glorious Revolution was called the “Glorious revolution” because there was no fighting in England and it guaranteed the power of Parliament
tip: The Glorious Revolution was called the “Glorious revolution” because there was no fighting in England and it guaranteed the power of Parliament

question: Which of these is a charity working with animals?
tip: People’s Dispensary for Sick Animals (PDSA)  is the charity that works with animals

question: Who directed the two British films ‘Brief Encounter’ and ‘Lawrence of Arabia’?
tip: Brief Encounter (1945), Lawrence of Arabia (1962) were directed by David Lean

question: Which TWO wives of Henry VIII were executed?
tip: Anne Boleyn – Anne Boleyn was English. She and Henry had one daughter, Elizabeth. Anne was unpopular in the country and was accused of taking lovers. She was executed at the Tower of London.Catherine Howard – Catherine was a cousin of Anne Boleyn. She was also accused of taking lovers and executed.

question: Which flower is associated with Northern Ireland?
tip: Shamrock is associated with Northern Ireland

question: When were women given the right to vote at the same age as men?
tip: In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights and the right to stand for Parliament, partly in recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War. Shortly before Emmeline’s death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

question: How many members does the UN Security Council have?
tip: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members. The UN was set up after the Second World War and aims to prevent war and promote international peace and security. There are 15 members on the UN Security Council, which recommends action when there are international crises and threats to peace. The UK is one of five permanent members of the Security Council.

question: What country did Britain fight against during the Crimean War?
tip: From 1853 to 1856, Britain fought with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War. It was the first war to be extensively covered by the media through news stories and photographs. Many soldiers died from illnesses they caught in the hospitals, rather than from war wounds. Queen Victoria introduced the Victoria Cross medal during this war.

question: Who invented the Internet as we know it today? (World Wide Web)
tip: The inventor of the World Wide Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee (1955–), is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.

question: What did R. A. Butler introduce?
options: Free university education in the UK
tip: R.A. Butler oversaw the introduction of the Education Act 1944 (often called ‘The Butler Act’), which introduced free secondary education in England and Wales.

question: People living in the UK must pay tax on which of the following TWO?
options: Income from property, savings and dividends
answers: Income from property, savings and dividends
tip: People in the UK have to pay tax on their income, which includes:

question: National Insurance is needed if you wish to work in the UK
tip: Almost everybody in the UK who is in paid work, including self-employed people, must pay National Insurance Contributions. The money raised from National Insurance Contributions is used to pay for state benefits and services such as the state retirement pension and the National Health Service (NHS).

question: The small claims procedure in Scotland and Northern Ireland is used for claims of less than what amount?
tip: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales; £5,000 in Scotland and £3,000 in Northern Ireland.

question: What do you have to pay tax on in the UK?
tip: People in the UK have to pay tax on their income, which includes:

question: When is Vaisakhi celebrated?
tip: Vaisakhi (also spelled Baisakhi) is a Sikh festival which celebrates the founding of the Sikh community known as the Khalsa. It is celebrated on 14 April each year with parades, dancing and singing.

question: When did the first professional football clubs form?
tip: Football is the UK’s most popular sport. It has a long history in the UK and the first professional football clubs were formed in the late 19th century.

question: What are the MPs who don’t represent a political party called?
tip: There are a few MPs who do not represent any of the main political parties. They are called ‘independents’ and usually represent an issue important to their constituency.

question: When did the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms establish in Britain?
tip: Britain was invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons. The languages they spoke are the basis of modern-day English. Battles were fought against these invaders but, by about AD 600, Anglo-Saxon kingdoms were established in Britain.

question: By which year did the English rule an area around Dublin called the Pale?
tip: At the beginning of the Middle Ages, Ireland was an independent country. The English first went to Ireland as troops to help the Irish king and remained to build their own settlements. By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin. Some of the important lords in other parts of Ireland accepted the authority of the English king.

question: Who designed the Dumfries House in Scotland?
tip: In the 18th century, simpler designs became popular. The Scottish architect Robert Adam influenced the development of architecture in the UK, Europe and America. He designed the inside decoration as well as the building itself in great houses such as Dumfries House in Scotland. His ideas influenced architects in cities such as Bath, where the Royal Crescent was built.

question: What is ‘Snowdon’?
tip: Snowdonia is a national park in North Wales. It covers an area of 838 square miles (2,170 square kilometres). Its most well-known landmark is Snowdon, which is the highest mountain in Wales.

question: What do the National Insurance Contributions fund?
tip: Almost everybody in the UK who is in paid work, including self-employed people, must pay National Insurance Contributions. The money raised from National Insurance Contributions is used to pay for state benefits and services such as the state retirement pension and the National Health Service (NHS).

question: When was Charles I executed?
tip: The king’s army was defeated at the Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby. By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war. Charles was held prisoner by the parliamentary army. He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.

question: When was the Emancipation Act signed?
tip: In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire. The Royal Navy stopped slave ships from other countries, freed the slaves and punished the slave traders.

question: When was the famous satirical magazine ‘Punch’ published?
tip: In the 19th century, satirical magazines began to be published. The most famous was ‘Punch’, which was published for the first time in the 1840s. Today, political cartoons continue to be published in newspapers, and magazines such as Private Eye continue the tradition of satire.

question: Ulster fry is a traditional food of which country?
tip: Northern Ireland’s traditional food is ‘Ulster fry’ – a fried meal with bacon, eggs, sausage, black pudding, white pudding, tomatoes, mushrooms, soda bread and potato bread.

question: What is an example of a Criminal Offence?
tip: Examples of criminal laws are: Carrying a weapon, selling or buying drugs, racial crime, selling tobacco to under 18s, smoking/drining in public in inappropriate places, buying alcohol for under 18s.

question: Where can you see the ‘Bayeux Tapestry’ today?
tip: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror. The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

question: Who tells visitors about the history of the Tower of London?
tip: The Tower of London was first built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066. Tours are given by the Yeoman Warders, also known as Beefeaters, who tell visitors about the building’s history. People can also see the Crown Jewels there.

question: Who appoints the members of the Cabinet?
tip: The Prime Minister appoints about 20 senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments which together form the cabinet.

question: What became the symbol of the House of Tudor?
tip: This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose. The war ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485 the House of Lancaster won. The symbol of the House of Tudor was a red rose with a white rose inside it as a sign that the Houses of York and Lancaster were now allies.

question: How many member states does the Commonwealth have?
tip: The Queen is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 53 member states. Membership is voluntary.

question: What percentage of the UK population doesn’t follow a religion?
tip: In the 2009 Citizenship Survey, 21% of people said that they had no religion.

question: What county is ‘Maiden Castle’ in?
tip: A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

question: Who sat in the House of Commons in the Middle Ages?
tip: In the middle ages, the nobility, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords. Knights, who were usually smaller landowners, and wealthy people from towns and cities were elected to sit in the House of Commons.

question: When did Queen Elizabeth II celebrate her Diamond Jubilee?
tip: Big Ben tower is named ‘Elizabeth Tower’ in honour of Queen Elizabeth II’s Diamond Jubilee in 2012.

question: When did Britain recognise the American colonies’ independence?
tip: In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments. The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain recognised the colonies’ independence in 1783.

question: What is the only major golf tournament held outside of the US?
tip: The Open Championship is the only ‘Major’ golf tournament held outside the United States. It is hosted by a different golf course every year.

question: Where do you have to be registered to be able to vote?
tip: To be able to vote in a parliamentary, local or European election, you must have your name on the electoral register.

question: What was an important English export in the Middle Ages?
tip: English wool became a very important export in the middle ages. People came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Many had special skills, such as weavers from France, engineers from Germany, glass manufacturers from Italy and canal builders from Holland.

question: When did the Vikings first attack Britain?
tip: The Vikings came from Denmark and Norway. They first visited Britain in AD 789 to raid coastal towns and take away goods and slaves.

question: How many members does the Scottish Parliament have?
tip: There are 129 members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs), elected by a form of proportional representation. question: Who designed New Delhi to be the seat of government in India?
tip: In the 20th century, Sir Edwin Lutyens had an influence throughout the British Empire. He designed New Delhi to be the seat of government in India. He was responsible for many war memorials throughout the world, including the Cenotaph in Whitehall.

question: Who led the team of scientists to ‘split the atom’ for the first time?
tip: Scientists led by Ernest Rutherford, working at Manchester and then Cambridge University, were the first to ‘split the atom’ and took part in the Manhattan Project in the United States, which developed the atomic bomb.

question: What was the ‘Black Death’?
tip: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.

question: Who won gold medals for ice dancing at the Olympic Games in 1984?
options: Bobby Moore and Dame Kelly Holmes
tip: Jayne Torvill (1957–) and Christopher Dean (1958–) won gold medals for ice dancing at the Olympic Games in 1984 and in four consecutive world championships.

question: What percentage of the total population lives in England?
tip: The population is very unequally distributed over the four parts of the UK. England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8% and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

question: What is meant by ‘common law’?
options: Sentence is decided by the jury
tip: In England, judges developed ‘common law’ by a process of precedence (that is, following previous decisions) and tradition. In Scotland, the legal system developed slightly differently and laws were ‘codified’ (that is, written down).

question: The Civil War in 1642 split the country into which two groups?
options: House of York and House of Lancaster
House of Commons and House of Lords
tip: Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

question: Who was R. A. Butler?
tip: Richard Austen Butler (later Lord Butler) was born in 1902. He became a Conservative MP in 1923 and held several positions before becoming responsible for education in 1941.

question: Who was the first ‘Scottish King’?
tip: In the north, the threat of attack by Vikings had encouraged the people to unite under one king, Kenneth MacAlpin. The term Scotland began to be used to describe that country.

question: When did the Irish Free State become a republic?
tip: In 1922 Ireland became two countries. The six counties in the north which were mainly Protestant remained part of the UK under the name Northern Ireland. The rest of Ireland became the Irish Free State. It had its own government and became a republic in 1949.

question: What party won the election in 1945 (After WWII)?
tip: In 1945 the British people elected a Labour government. The new Prime Minister was Clement Atlee, who promised to introduce the welfare state outlined in the Beveridge Report. In 1948, Aneurin (Nye) Bevan, the Minister for Health, led the establishment of the National Health Service (NHS), which guaranteed a minimum standard of health care for all, free at the point of use.

question: Who wrote music for King George I?
tip: The German-born composer George Frederick Handel (1695–1759) spent many years in the UK and became a British citizen in 1727. He wrote the Water Music for King George I and Music for the Royal Fireworks for his son, George II.

question: How many people lost their lives in the decades after 1969 due to violence in Northern Ireland?
tip: Some 3,000 people lost their lives in the decades after 1969 in the violence in Northern Ireland.

question: Who should you write to if you wish to make a complaint about the Police?
tip: Anyone can make a complaint about the police by going to a police station or writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved.

question: Where is the Hadrian Wall?
tip: Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).

question: Which was a crucial aerial battle against the Germans?
tip: The Germans waged an air campaign against Britain, but the British resisted with their fighter planes and eventually won the crucial aerial battle against the Germans, called ‘the Battle of Britain’.

question: Who wrote the Canterbury Tales?
tip: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told called The Canterbury Tales.

question: What is Richard Arkwright remembered for?
tip: Born in 1732, Arkwright originally trained and worked as a barber. He was able to dye hair and make wigs. When wigs became less popular, he started to work in textiles. He improved the original carding machine. Arkwright is particularly remembered for the efficient and profitable way that he ran his factories.

question: Which court deals with the most serious cases in Scotland?
tip: The most serious cases in Scotland, such as murder, are heard at a High Court with a judge and jury.

question: Who is the Patron St of Wales?
tip: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day:

question: Who is responsible for the economy?
tip: The Prime Minister appoints about 20 senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments. These include:

question: What does the York Minster have?
tip: York Minster  had windows of stained glass, telling stories about the Bible and Christian saints.

question: What percentage of the UK population is Muslim?
tip: The UK is historically a Christian country. In the 2009 Citizenship Survey, 70% of people identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Muslim (4%), Hindu (2%), Sikh (1%), Jewish or Buddhist (both less than 0.5%), and 2% of people followed another religion.

question: What was the purpose of the Emancipation Act?
options: No one could be held prisoner unlawfully
Abolish slavery in the British Empire
answers: Abolish slavery in the British Empire
tip: In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

question: How many colonies were granted independence in 1947?
tip: Another aspect of change was self-government for former colonies. In 1947, independence was granted to nine countries, including India, Pakistan and Ceylon (now Sri Lanka). Other colonies in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific achieved independence over the next 20 years.

question: Which of these is an Anglo-Saxon poem?
tip: The Anglo-Saxon poem ‘Beowulf’ tells of its hero’s battles against monsters and is still translated into modern English.

question: Which of these words is based on Norman words?
tip: Some words in modern English – for example, ‘park’ and ‘beauty’ – are based on Norman French words. Others – for example, ‘apple’, ‘cow’ and ‘summer’ – are based on Anglo-Saxon words.

question: How many AMs does the Welsh government have?
tip: The Welsh government and National Assembly for Wales are based in Cardiff, the capital city of Wales. The National Assembly has 60 Assembly members (AMs) and elections are held every four years using a form of proportional representation. Members can speak in either Welsh or English and all of the Assembly’s publications are in both languages.

question: What tools did the Bronze age people introduce?
tip: The people of the Bronze Age were accomplished metalworkers who made many beautiful objects in bronze and gold, including tools, ornaments and weapons.

question: Who is Sir Chris Hoy?
tip: Sir Chris Hoy (1976–) is a Scottish cyclist who has won six gold and one silver Olympic medals. He has also won 11 world championship titles.

question: What does the UN aim to do?
tip: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members. The UN was set up after the Second World War and aims to prevent war and promote international peace and security.

question: What do many theatres in the UK produce at Christmas time?
tip: One British tradition is the pantomime. Many theatres produce a pantomime at Christmas time. They are based on fairy stories and are light-hearted plays with music and comedy, enjoyed by family audiences. One of the traditional characters is the Dame, a woman played by a man.

question: What was ‘Shampooing’ when it was first introduced?
options: The Indian art of head massage
answers: The Indian art of head massage
tip: Mahomet and his wife also introduced ‘shampooing’, the Indian art of head massage, to Britain.

question: Which was the last successful invasion of Britain?
tip: The Norman Conquest was the last successful foreign invasion of England and led to many changes in government and social structures in England.

question: What county does Stonehenge stand in?
tip: Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire. Stonehenge was probably a special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies.

question: When was the time of growing patriotism?
tip: The Elizabethan period in England was a time of growing patriotism: a feeling of pride in being English. English explorers sought new trade routes and tried to expand British trade into the Spanish colonies in the Americas.

question: What is the capital of Scotland?
tip: Edinburgh is the capital city of Scotland.

question: Who appoints the local Chief Constable?
tip: PCCs (Police and Crime Commissioners) set local police priorities and the local policing budget. They also appoint the Chief Constable.

question: Haggis is a traditional food of which country?
tip: Scotland’s food is Haggis – a sheep’s stomach stuffed with offal, suet, onions and oatmeal.

question: How many National Parks are there in the UK?
tip: There are 15 national parks in England, Wales and Scotland. They are areas of protected countryside that everyone can visit, and where people live, work and look after the landscape.

question: What yearly event happens between Oxford and Cambridge Universities?
tip: Rowing is also popular, both as a leisure activity and as a competitive sport. There is a popular yearly race on the Thames between Oxford and Cambridge Universities.

question: When were the last Welsh rebellions defeated?
tip: By the middle of the 15th century the last Welsh rebellions had been defeated. English laws and the English language were introduced.

question: Which of the Houses is more important in today’s Britain?
tip: The House of Commons is regarded as the more important of the two chambers in Parliament because its members are democratically elected.

question: What university did Isaac Newton attend?
tip: Born in Lincolnshire, eastern England, Isaac Newton first became interested in science when he studied at Cambridge University. He became an important figure in the field. His most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica ‘Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy’, which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe.

question: Which is not a Protestant Christian group?
tip: There is no established Church in Wales or Northern Ireland. Other Protestant Christian groups in the UK are Baptists, Methodists, Presbyterians and Quakers. There are also other denominations of Christianity, the biggest of which is Roman Catholic.

question: What is Diwali often called?
tip: Diwali normally falls in October or November and lasts for five days. It is often called the Festival of Lights. It is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs. It celebrates the victory of good over evil and the gaining of knowledge. There are different stories about how the festival came about. There is a famous celebration of Diwali in Leicester.

question: What happens at 11:00 on the Remembrance Day?
tip: Remembrance Day, 11 November, commemorates those who died fighting for the UK and its allies. Originally it commemorated the dead of the First World War, which ended on 11 November 1918. People wear poppies (the red flower found on the battlefields of the First World War). At 11.00 am there is a two-minute silence and wreaths are laid at the Cenotaph in Whitehall, London.

question: Who became famous in silent movies for his tramp character?
tip: Sir Charles (Charlie) Chaplin became famous in silent movies for his tramp character and was one of many British actors to make a career in Hollywood.

question: Which of these was a British plane in WWII?
tip: The most important planes used by the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain were the Spitfire and the Hurricane – which were designed and built in Britain.

question: What is the most famous rugby tournament?
tip: The most famous rugby union competition is the Six Nations Championship between England, Ireland, Scotland, Wales, France and Italy. The Super League is the most well-known rugby league (club) competition.

question: Which of these is known as West End in London?
tip: There are theatres in most towns and cities throughout the UK, ranging from the large to the small. London’s West End, also known as ‘Theatreland’, is particularly well known.

question: What percentage of the total population lives in Scotland?
tip: The population is very unequally distributed over the four parts of the UK. England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8% and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

question: Who developed important Economics ideas?
tip: Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish. Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today.

question: What was encouraged to develop the UK economy in 1950?
tip: During the 1950s, there was still a shortage of labour in the UK. Further immigration was therefore encouraged for economic reasons, and many industries advertised for workers from overseas.

question: When did many Scottish people leave for North America?
tip: A process began which became known as the ‘Highland Clearances’. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as ‘crofts’) to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle. Evictions became very common in the early 19th century. Many Scottish people left for North America at this time.

question: What is the country house owned by the Prime Minister called?
tip: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street, in central London, near the Houses of Parliament. He or she also has a country house outside London called Chequers.

question: What is the maximum fine if you watch TV without a valid TV licence?
tip: You will receive a fine of up to £1,000 if you watch TV but do not have a TV licence.

question: What was the Spanish Armada?
tip: Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

question: Which movement campaigned for the women’s rights?
tip: In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, an increasing number of women campaigned and demonstrated for greater rights and, in particular, the right to vote. They formed the women’s suffrage movement and became known as ‘suffragettes’.

question: During Slave trade, where did slaves primarily come from?
tip: Slaves came primarily from West Africa. Travelling on British ships in horrible conditions, they were taken to America and the Caribbean, where they were made to work on tobacco and sugar plantations.

question: How many years did Charles I try to rule without Parliament?
tip: For 11 years, Charles I found ways in which to raise money without Parliament’s approval but eventually trouble in Scotland meant that he had to recall Parliament.

question: What is MP’s responsibility?
options: To represent everyone in their constituency
To represent everyone in the UK
To get as many votes as possible
answers: To represent everyone in their constituency
tip: MPs have a number of different responsibilities. They:

question: Where did many of the Viking settle after they got defeated?
tip: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings. Many of the Viking invaders stayed in Britain – especially in the east and north of England, in an area known as the Danelaw (many places names there, such as Grimsby and Scunthorpe, come from the Viking languages).

question: What is the longest distance on the mainland in the UK?
tip: The longest distance on the mainland is from John O’Groats on the north coast of Scotland to Land’s End in the south-west corner of England. It is about 870 miles (approximately 1,400 kilometres).

question: When were women given the right to vote at the age of 18?
tip: By 1918, the voting franchise was extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21. In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

question: Where is the Eden Project located?
tip: The Eden Project is located in Cornwall, in the south west of England. Its biomes, which are like giant greenhouses, house plants from all over the world. The Eden Project is also a charity which runs environmental and social projects internationally.

question: Which of the devolved administrations has been suspended a few times?
tip: There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999. There is a Northern Ireland Assembly, although this has been suspended on a few occasions.

question: Which Castles are in use to this day?
tip: Castles were built in many places in Britain and Ireland, partly for defence. Today many are in ruins, although some, such as Windsor and Edinburgh, are still in use.

question: What did the Magna Carta do?
tip: The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law. It protected the rights of the nobility and restricted the king’s power to collect taxes or to make or change laws.

question: What is an example of the Middle Ages architecture?
options: The White Tower in the Tower of London
answers: The White Tower in the Tower of London
tip: In the Middle Ages, great cathedrals and churches were built, many of which still stand today. Examples are the cathedrals in Durham, Lincoln, Canterbury and Salisbury. The White Tower in the Tower of London is an example of a Norman castle keep, built on the orders of William the Conqueror.

question: Which General remains a controversial figure in Ireland?
tip: Cromwell was successful in establishing the authority of the English Parliament in Ireland but did this with such violence that even today Cromwell remains a controversial figure.

question: When was the Giant’s Causeway formed?
tip: Located on the north-east coast of Northern Ireland, the Giant’s Causeway is a land formation of columns made from volcanic lava. It was formed about 50 million years ago. There are many legends about the Causeway and how it was formed.

question: What tells us about how people lived just after the Norman Conquest?
tip: William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.

question: How many times did Sir Jackie Stewart win the Formula 1 championship?
tip: Sir Jackie Stewart (1939–) is a Scottish former racing driver who won the Formula 1 world championship three times.

question: When did the first farmers arrive in Britain?
tip: The first farmers arrived in Britain about 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe. These people built houses, tombs and monuments on the land.

question: Where was William Shakespeare born?
tip: Shakespeare (1564-1616) was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England.

question: Who is the heir to the throne?
tip: The Queen’s eldest son, Prince Charles (the Prince of Wales), is the heir to the throne.

question: Who led the Scottish Army during the Battle of Bannockburn?
tip: In Scotland, the English kings were less successful. In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.

question: When did Protestant ideas begin to spread?
tip: Protestant ideas gradually gained strength in England, Wales and Scotland during the 16th century.

question: How long does Diwali normally last for?
tip: Diwali normally falls in October or November and lasts for five days. It is often called the Festival of Lights. It is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs. It celebrates the victory of good over evil and the gaining of knowledge. There are different stories about how the festival came about. There is a famous celebration of Diwali in Leicester.

question: When did the development of a free press happen?
tip: From 1695, newspapers were allowed to operate without a government licence. Increasing numbers of newspapers began to be published.

question: How many Russian and Polish Jews came to Britain between 1870-1914?
tip: People continued to come to Britain from other parts of the world. For example, between 1870 and 1914, around 120,000 Russian and Polish Jews came to Britain to escape persecution.

question: Which tribes invaded Britain after the Romans had left?
tip: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned. Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.

question: What was the most important principle of the Enlightenment?
options: Freedom of religion and political views
answers: Freedom of religion and political views
tip: One of the most important principles of the Enlightenment was that everyone should have the right to their own political and religious beliefs and that the state should not try to dictate to them.

question: What is the capital of Northern Ireland?
tip: Belfast is the capital city of Northern Ireland.

question: Where did the canal builders come from in the middle ages?
tip: People came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Many had special skills, such as weavers from France, engineers from Germany, glass manufacturers from Italy and canal builders from Holland.

question: How many years did Mary, the Queen of Scots spend in prison?
tip: Mary was Elizabeth I’s cousin and hoped that Elizabeth might help her, but Elizabeth suspected Mary of wanting to take over the English throne, and kept her a prisoner for 20 years. Mary was eventually executed, accused of plotting against Elizabeth I.

question: When did the Romans successfully invade Britain?
tip: Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC. This was unsuccessful and for nearly 100 years Britain remained separate from the Roman Empire. In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion. This time, there was resistance from some of the British tribes but the Romans were successful in occupying almost all of Britain.

question: Which of the events is the landing of allied forces in Normandy?
tip: On 6 June 1944, allied forces landed in Normandy (this event is often referred to as ‘D-Day’).

question: Who was the “Iron Duke” that defeated the Emperor Napoleon?
tip: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo. Wellington was known as the Iron Duke and later became Prime Minister.

question: When was the Scottish Parliament established?
tip: There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999.

question: How many ‘local authorities’ does the city of London have?
tip: London has 33 local authorities, with the Greater London Authority and the Mayor of London coordinating policies across the capital.

question: How old do you have to be to buy a lottery ticket or a scratch card?
tip: People under 16 are not allowed to participate in the National Lottery. This includes buying Scratch Cards.

question: Where can you find Boudicca, the Queen of the Iceni statue?
tip: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England. She is still remembered today and there is a statue of her on Westminster Bridge in London, near the Houses of Parliament.

question: When is St Patrick’s day?
tip: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day:

question: What is the ‘Divine Right of Kings’?
options: Reduced the power of the King
Reduced the power of the nobles
The King was Appointed by God
answers: The King was Appointed by God
tip: ‘Divine Right of Kings’ is the idea that the king was directly appointed by God to rule. The king should be able to act without having to seek approval from Parliament.

question: When did Queen Victoria become queen?
tip: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 18. She reigned until 1901, almost 64 years.

question: What were the refugees that came from France called?
tip: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.

question: When did Britain become separated from the continent?
tip: Britain only became permanently separated from the continent by the Channel about 10,000 years ago.

question: What was the population of the UK in 1998?
When is the Bonfire Night celebrated?
tip: Bonfire Night, 5 November, is an occasion when people in Great Britain set off fireworks at home or in special displays. The origin of this celebration was an event in 1605, when a group of Catholics led by Guy Fawkes failed in their plan to kill the Protestant king with a bomb in the Houses of Parliament.

question: When was the Magna Carta established?
tip: There were few formal limits to the king’s power until 1215. In that year, King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands. The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter). The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law. It protected the rights of the nobility and restricted the king’s power to collect taxes or to make or change laws.

question: What is the Mercury Music Prize awarded for?
options: The best music producer in the UK and Ireland
The best classical song in the UK and Ireland
The best song in the UK and Ireland
The best album from the UK and Ireland
answers: The best album from the UK and Ireland
tip: The Mercury Music Prize is awarded each September for the best album from the UK and Ireland. The Brit Awards is an annual event that gives awards in a range of categories, such as best British group and best British solo artist.

question: Who built the Hadrian’s Wall to keep out the Picts?
tip: Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).

question: Which British TV shows are popular in the UK now?
tip: Popular programmes include regular soap operas such as Coronation Street and EastEnders.

question: When did the “Battle of the Boyne” happen?
tip: James II wanted to regain the throne and invaded Ireland with the help of a French army. William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today. William re-conquered Ireland and James fled back to France.

question: Who led a team to clone a mammal for the first time?
options: Sir Ian Wilmot and Keith Campbell
answers: Sir Ian Wilmot and Keith Campbell
tip: In 1996, two British scientists, Sir Ian Wilmot (1944–) and Keith Campbell (1954–2012), led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly the sheep. This has led to further research into the possible use of cloning to preserve endangered species and for medical purposes.

question: How is the New Year often called in Scotland?
tip: Known in Scotland as ‘The Bard’, Robert Burns was a Scottish poet. His best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).

question: What were the Canterbury Tales about?
options: The stories people told each other
answers: The stories people told each other
tip: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.

question: Which of Henry VIII’s wives were executed?
options: Catherine Parr and Anne of Cleves
Catherine of Aragon and Anne Boleyn
Anne of Cleves and Jane Seymour
tip: Anne Boleyn was English. She and Henry had one daughter, Elizabeth. Anne was unpopular in the country and was accused of taking lovers. She was executed at the Tower of London. Catherine was a cousin of Anne Boleyn. She was also accused of taking lovers and executed.

question: What was the main crop in Ireland in the 19th century?
tip: In the 19th century, many people in Ireland depended on potatoes as a large part of their diet. In the middle of the century the potato crop failed, and Ireland suffered a famine. A million people died from disease and starvation.

question: Who is Andy Murray?

question: What was build as part of the UK’s celebration of the new millennium?

tip: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.

question: Which play was written by Shakespeare?

question: What does an aged population have an impact on?
tip: People in the UK are living longer than ever before. This is due to improved living standards and better health care. There are now a record number of people aged 85 and over. This has an impact on the cost of pensions and health care.

question: What information about you is asked at the polling station?
options: Your name, contact details and age
tip: When you arrive at the polling station, the staff will ask for your name and address. In Northern Ireland you will also have to show photographic identification.

question: Who became the first Briton to win the Tour de France?
tip: Bradley Wiggins (1980–) is a cyclist. In 2012, he became the first Briton to win the Tour de France. He has won seven Olympic medals, including gold medals in the 2004, 2008 and 2012 Olympic Games.

question: What service can you use to find a lawyer or a solicitor?
tip: The Citizens Advice Bureau can give you names of local solicitors and which areas of law they specialise in. You can also get this information from the Law Society.

question: When did the UK join the EU?
tip: The UK originally decided not to join the EU (European Union) but it became a member in 1973. There are now 28 EU member states.

tip: Joseph Turner (1775–1851) was an influential landscape painter in a modern style. He is considered the artist who raised the profile of landscape painting.

question: Which flower is associated with Northern Ireland?
tip: A shamrock is associated with Northern Ireland. A rose is associated with England, a thistle with Scotland and a daffodil with Wales.

question: Where are the youth cases heard in Scotland?

tip: In Scotland a system called the Children’s Hearings System is used to deal with children and young people who have committed an offence.

question: What UK landmark was voted as Britain’s favourite view?
tip: The Lake District is England’s largest national park. It covers 885 square miles (2,292 square kilometres). It is famous for its lakes and mountains and is very popular with climbers, walkers and sailors. The biggest stretch of water is Windermere. In 2007, television viewers voted Wastwater as Britain’s favourite view.

question: What celebrates the end of Ramadan?
tip: Eid al-Fitr celebrates the end of Ramadan, when Muslims have fasted for a month. They thank Allah for giving them the strength to complete the fast.

question: Who developed a radar?
tip: Radar was developed by Scotsman Sir Robert Watson-Watt (1892–1973), who proposed that enemy aircraft could be detected by radio waves. The first successful radar test took place in 1935.

question: What is the main purpose of the Opposition?
options: To represent the people of the UK

question: What programme helps teenagers develop their skills?
tip: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

question: How often do you have to take the MOT test for an old vehicle?
tip: If your vehicle is over three years old, you must take it for a Ministry of Transport (MOT) test every year. It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than three years old.

question: When did Scotland abolish the authority of the Pope?
tip: Scotland had also been strongly influenced by Protestant ideas. In 1560, the predominantly Protestant Scottish Parliament abolished the authority of the Pope in Scotland and Roman Catholic religious services became illegal.

question: Who tried to arrest 5 parliamentary leaders from the House of Commons?
tip: Charles I entered the House of Commons and tried to arrest five parliamentary leaders, but they had been warned and were not there. This led to the English Civil war in 1642.

question: What treaty was signed in 1707?

tip: The Act of Union, known as the Treaty of Union in Scotland, was therefore agreed in 1707, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain.

question: Who led the Labour Government from 2007 to 2010?
tip: Gordon Brown took over as Prime Minister in 2007 and led the Labour Party.

question: Where does the Scottish Grand National take place?
tip: Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; the Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr. There is a National Horseracing Museum in Newmarket, Suffolk.

question: Who first introduced James Bond?
tip: Ian Fleming’s books introduced James Bond.

question: What is an important part of the UK character?
options: To have fish and chips every lunch
The ability to laugh at ourselves
Go to the pub every Friday
answers: The ability to laugh at ourselves
tip: The traditions of comedy and satire, and the ability to laugh at ourselves, are an important part of the UK character.

question: What do you require by law to watch TV using any medium?
Which country invented Cricket?
tip: Cricket originated in England and is now played in many countries. Games can last up to five days but still result in a draw! The most famous Cricket competition is the Ashes, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia.

question: What country is Swansea in?
tip: Swansea is a Welsh city.

question: What is the day before Lent called?
tip: The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent. The day before Lent starts is called Shrove Tuesday, or Pancake Day.

question: When did the English Civil war begin?
tip: Civil war between the king and Parliament began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

question: Who were the first people to start living in Britain?
tip: The first people to live in Britain were hunter-gatherers, in what we call the Stone Age.

question: What were the working conditions like during the Industrial Revolution?
tip: Working conditions during the Industrial Revolution were very poor. There were no laws to protect employees, who were often forced to work long hours in dangerous situations. Children also worked and were treated in the same way as adults.

question: Which of these venues is located in Greenwich?
tip: There are many large venues that host music events throughout the year, such as: The O2 in Greenwich and the Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre (SECC) in Glasgow.

question: Who is responsible for crime and immigration?
tip: Home Secretary is responsible for crime, policing and immigration.

question: Which party formed the government in 2010?
tip: In May 2010, and for the first time in the UK since February 1974, no political party won an overall majority in the General Election. The Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties formed a coalition and the leader of the Conservative Party, David Cameron, became Prime Minister.

question: What organisations try to influence government policy?
tip: Pressure and lobby groups are organisations which try to influence government policy. They play an important role in politics.

question: Which river banks the London eye?
tip: The London Eye is situated on the southern bank of the River Thames and is a Ferris wheel that is 443 feet (135 metres) tall. It was originally built as part of the UK’s celebration of the new millennium and continues to be an important part of New Year celebrations.

question: What is the Church of England usually known as in other countries?
tip: The official Church of the state is the Church of England, called the Anglican Church in other countries and the Episcopal Church in Scotland and the United States.

question: How many member states does the UN have?
tip: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members.

question: Which Scottish poet wrote “The Bruce”?
tip: In Scotland, many people continued to speak Gaelic and the Scots language also developed. A number of poets began to write in the Scots language. One example is John Barbour, who wrote The Bruce about the Battle of Bannockburn.

question: What did the Chartists campaign for?

Every man to have a vote

question: When did the English defeat the Spanish Armada?
tip: Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

question: Which country(s) did Britain fight against during the Battle of Trafalgar?
tip: Britain’s navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.

question: What medal was introduced during the Crimean War?
tip: Queen Victoria introduced the Victoria Cross medal during the Crimean war. It honours acts of valour by soldiers.

question: What event is known as the evacuation of 300,000 people from the beaches?
tip: Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase ‘the Dunkirk spirit’.

question: Why is it called ‘The Glorious Revolution’?

tip: This event was later called the ‘Glorious Revolution’ because there was no fighting in England and because it guaranteed the power of Parliament, ending the threat of a monarch ruling on his or her own as he or she wished.

question: Who lost a lot of their power after the Battle of Culloden in 1746?
tip: The clans lost a lot of their power and influence after Culloden. Chieftains became landlords if they had the favour of the English king, and clansmen became tenants who had to pay for the land they used.

question: Where did the Vikings come from?
tip: The Vikings came from Denmark and Norway. They first visited Britain in AD 789 to raid coastal towns and take away goods and slaves.

question: What is the “King James” Bible?
tip: One achievement of King James’ reign was a new translation of the Bible into English. This translation is known as the ‘King James Version’ or the ‘Authorised Version’. It was not the first English Bible but is a version which continues to be used in many Protestant churches today.

question: Who designed the Cenotaph?
tip: Sir Edwin Lutyens was responsible for many war memorials throughout the world, including the Cenotaph in Whitehall. The Cenotaph is the site of the annual Remembrance Day service attended by the Queen and many others.

question: How many Houses did the Scottish Parliament have in the middle ages?
tip: In the middle ages the Scottish Parliament had three Houses, called Estates: the lords, the commons and the clergy.

question: Where do the Laurence Olivier Awards take place?
tip: The Laurence Olivier Awards take place annually at different venues in London. There are a variety of categories, including best director, best actor and best actress. The awards are named after the British actor Sir Laurence Olivier, later Lord Olivier, who was best known for his roles in various Shakespeare plays.

question: What can schools do to raise money?
options: Ask the local council for extra funding
tip: Many schools organise events to raise money for extra equipment or out-of-school activities. Activities might include book sales, toy sales or bringing food to sell.

question: How long is Hannukah celebrated for?
tip: Hannukah is in November or December and is celebrated for eight days. It is to remember the Jews’ struggle for religious freedom. On each day of the festival a candle is lit on a stand of eight candles (called a menorah) to remember the story of the festival, where oil that should have lasted only a day did so for eight.

question: How long does it take to give blood?
tip: Donated blood is used by hospitals to help people with a wide range of injuries and illnesses, it takes about an hour to do so.

question: How many times has the UK hosted the Olympic Games?
tip: The UK has hosted the Olympic Games on three occasions: 1908, 1948 and 2012. The main Olympic site for the 2012 Games was in Stratford, East London.

question: Which clan was killed because of not taking an oath?
tip: All Scottish clans were required formally to accept William as king by taking an oath. The MacDonalds of Glencoe were late in taking the oath and were all killed.

question: Who invaded the Falkland Islands in 1982?
tip: In 1982, Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands, a British overseas territory in the South Atlantic.

question: When did the Glorious Revolution happen?
tip: In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. When William reached England, there was no resistance. This event was later called the ‘Glorious Revolution’ because there was no fighting in England and because it guaranteed the power of Parliament, ending the threat of a monarch ruling on his or her own as he or she wished.

question: What is known as the Bessemer process?
tip: The development of the Bessemer process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways.

question: What is the British Constitution often described as?
tip: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as ‘unwritten’. This is mainly because the UK, unlike America or France, has never had a revolution which led permanently to a totally new system of government.

question: How many members does a jury have in Scotland?
tip: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members, and in Scotland a jury has 15 members.

question: Where is the best preserved prehistoric village “Skara Brae on Orkney” located?
tip: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

question: What is an example of a Criminal Offence?

question: What does the “R” Plate stand for?
tip: In Northern Ireland, a newly qualified driver must display an ‘R’ plate (for restricted driver) for one year after passing the test.

question: Which of these are British Overseas Territories?
options: The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man
St Helena and the Isle of Man
tip: There are also several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as St Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are also linked to the UK but are not a part of it.

question: Who discovered Insulin?
tip: The Scottish physician and researcher John MacLeod (1876–1935) was the co-discoverer of insulin, used to treat diabetes.

question: How long is the Bayeux Tapestry?
tip: The Battle of Hastings is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry which is 70 meters long.

question: Who is able to change the Prime Minister during his/her term?
tip: The Prime Minister can be changed if the MPs in the governing party decide to do so, or if he or she wishes to resign. The Prime Minister usually resigns if his or her party loses a General Election.

question: What percentage of the work force are women?
tip: Women in Britain today make up about half of the workforce. On average, girls leave school with better qualifications than boys. More women than men study at university.

question: Which organization looks after the Edinburgh Castle?
tip: The Edinburgh Castle has a long history, dating back to the early Middle Ages. It is looked after by Historic Scotland, a Scottish government agency.

question: Where did Charles II hide to escape from Cromwell’s army?
tip: Charles II escaped from Worcester, famously hiding in an oak tree on one occasion, and eventually fled to Europe.

question: Why was Mary known as “Bloody Mary”?
options: She put her sister in prison
tip: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants.

question: What was the purpose of the Corn Laws in 1846?
options: To prevent the import of cheap grain
answers: To prevent the import of cheap grain
tip: Corn Laws in 1846 had prevented the import of cheap grain.

question: Where can you get help if you can’t afford to pay a vet?
tip: Vaccinations and medical treatment for animals are available from veterinary surgeons (vets). There are charities which may help people who cannot afford to pay a vet.

question: What is the responsibility that you have as a UK citizen?
options: Look after yourself and your family
answers: Look after yourself and your family
tip: Flowing from the fundamental principles are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK and which we expect all residents to respect.

question: When did the Parliament begin developing into the institution it is now?
