question: How many member states does the Commonwealth have?
tip: The Queen is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 53 member states.

question: What happens if an MP dies or resigns?
options: A new General Election is held
The closest MP will have to cover
tip: If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called a byelection, in his or her constituency.

question: What was the estimated population of the British Empire?
tip: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa. It became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people.

question: When did the BBC start the first radio broadcast?
tip: The BBC started radio broadcasts in 1922 and began the world’s first regular television service in 1936.

question: Who set up the first formal anti-slavery campaigns?
tip: The first formal anti-slavery groups were set up by the Quakers in the late 1700s, and they petitioned Parliament to ban the practice.

question: When did English become the official language for documents?
tip: By 1400, in England, official documents were being written in English, and English had become the preferred language of the royal court and Parliament.

question: Who ordered to write the Book of Common Prayer?
tip: Henry VIII was succeeded by his son Edward VI, who was strongly Protestant. During his reign, the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England.

question: What does the Turner Prize celebrate?
tip: The Turner Prize was established in 1984 and celebrates contemporary art.

question: Where is the Millennium Stadium located?
tip: Sporting events take place at major stadiums such as Wembley Stadium in London and the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff.

question: What is the official name of the country?
options: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
answers: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
tip: The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. ‘Great Britain’ refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland.

question: What percentage of the total population lives in Wales?
tip: UK population is very unequally distributed over the four parts of the UK. Wales makes around 5%.

question: What did the Romans introduce to Britain?
tip: The Romans remained in Britain for 400 years. They built roads and public buildings, created a structure of law, and introduced new plants and animals.

question: When were the women given the right to vote at the same age as men?
tip: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women’s Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. Shortly before Emmeline’s death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

question: When did England win the World Cup?
tip: Bobby Moore (1941–93) captained the English football team that won the World Cup in 1966.

question: Which party did Margaret Thatcher belong to?
tip: Margaret Thatcher, Britain’s first woman Prime Minister, led the Conservative government from 1979 to 1990.

question: Who won the Wars of the Roses?
tip: This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose. The war ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485. King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII.

question: Who is a Patron St of Scotland?
tip: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day:

question: Who was the first Danish King?
tip: The first Danish King was Cnut, also called Canute.

question: What is the period after the Norman Conquest up until 1485 called?
tip: The period after the Norman Conquest up until about 1485 is called the Middle Ages or the medieval period. It was a time of almost constant war.

question: Who was the first man to be called the ‘Prime Minister’?
tip: The first man to be called ‘Prime Minister’ was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

question: Who wrote “The Lord of the Rings”?
tip: The Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien was voted the country’s best-loved novel in 2003.

question: Which languages were the basis of modern English?
tip: After the Norman Conquest, the king and his noblemen had spoken Norman French and the peasants had continued to speak Anglo-Saxon. Gradually these two languages combined to become one English language.

question: How many American colonies declared their independence in 1776?
tip: In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments. The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain recognised the colonies’ independence in 1783.

question: How often do the ministers meet to discuss important issues?
tip: Ministers form the cabinet, a committee which usually meets weekly and makes important decisions about government policy. Many of these decisions have to be debated or approved by Parliament.

question: Who is currently the Head of State of the UK?
tip: Queen Elizabeth II is the head of state of the UK. She is also the monarch or head of state for many countries in the Commonwealth.

question: When did the “Battle of Agincourt” take place?
tip: One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V’s vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French. The English left France in the 1450s.

question: Which of these is not a music festival?
tip: The Edinburgh Festival takes place in Edinburgh, Scotland, every summer. The Fringe (One of the festivals) is a showcase of mainly theatre and comedy performances.

question: What is the Turner Prize given for?
tip: The Turner Prize is recognised as one of the most prestigious visual art awards in Europe. Previous winners include Damien Hirst and Richard Wright.

question: When did the UK join the EEC?
tip: West Germany, France, Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands formed the European Economic Community (EEC) in 1957. At first the UK did not wish to join the EEC but it eventually did so in 1973.

question: What’s the age requirement to drink wine with a meal with someone over 18?
tip: 16 year olds can drink wine or beer with a meal in a hotel or restaurant as long as they are with someone over 18.

question: How many members does The Northern Ireland Assembly have?
tip: The Northern Ireland Assembly was established soon after the Belfast Agreement (or Good Friday Agreement) in 1998. There is a power-sharing agreement which distributes ministerial Offices amongst the main parties. The Assembly has 108 elected members, known as MLAs (members of the Legislative Assembly). They are elected with a form of proportional representation.

question: Who was the Prime Minister during 1945-1951?
tip: Clement Attlee was born in London in 1883. He was Prime Minister from 1945 to 1951 and led the Labour Party for 20 years.

question: What did the Statute of Rhuddlan do?
tip: In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England.

question: When were films first shown in the UK?
tip: Films were first shown publicly in the UK in 1896 and film screenings very quickly became popular.

question: Who established the Church of England?
tip: To divorce his first wife, Henry VIII needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

question: When was the first coin in Britain made?
tip: The Iron Age people made the first coins to be minted in Britain, some inscribed with the names of Iron Age kings.

question: Where does the UK government sit?
tip: The UK is governed by the parliament sitting in Westminster.

question: How long can you use an EU driving licence for?
tip: If your driving licence is from a country in the European Union (EU), Iceland, Liechtenstein or Norway, you can drive in the UK for as long as your licence is valid. If you have a licence from any other country, you may use it in the UK for up to 12 months.

question: When is Valentine’s Day?
tip: Valentine’s Day, 14 February, is when lovers exchange cards and gifts. Sometimes people send anonymous cards to someone they secretly admire.

question: Where did the supporters of Charles Edward Stuart come from?
tip: Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland. He was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised an army.

question: Who designed the Clifton Suspension Bridge?
tip: Brunel was originally from Portsmouth, England. He was an engineer who built tunnels, bridges, railway lines and ships. He was responsible for constructing the Great Western Railway and the Clifton Suspension Bridge.

question: Where was one of the Anglo Saxon kings buried with treasure and armour?
tip: The burial place of one of the kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk.  This king was buried with treasure and armour, all placed in a ship which was then covered by a mound of earth. Scotland and Wales remained free of Anglo Saxon rule.

question: Which of the events is the bombing of English cities by the Germans?
tip: The Blitz was the German air force bombing London and other British cities at night-time. The phrase ‘the Blitz spirit’ is still used today to describe Britons pulling together in the face of adversity.

question: What helped the progress of the industrial revolution?
tip: Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt’s work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

question: When did the Habeas Corpus Act become law?
tip: The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679. This was a very important piece of legislation which remains relevant today. Habeas corpus is Latin for ‘you must present the person in court’. The Act guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully. Every prisoner has a right to a court hearing.

question: Who can get a 50% discount on their TV licence?
tip: People over 75 can apply for a free TV licence and blind people can get a 50% discount.

question: Who was the first woman Prime Minister?
tip: In 1979, Margaret Thatcher became the first woman Prime Minister of the UK. She was the longest-serving Prime Minister of the 20th century, remaining in Office until 1990.

question: What does the UK offer to its residents?
What is the National Anthem of the UK?
tip: The National Anthem of the UK is ‘God Save the Queen’. It is played at important national occasions and at events attended by the Queen or the Royal Family. The first verse is: ‘God save our gracious Queen! Long live our noble Queen! God save the Queen! Send her victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us, God save the Queen!’.

question: Which word comes from the Viking language?
tip: Grimsby and Scunthorpe are the examples of words that come from the Viking languages.

question: Which operas were written by Gilbert and Sullivan?
tip: Gilbert and Sullivan wrote comic operas, often making fun of popular culture and politics. These operas include HMS Pinafore, The Pirates of Penzance and The Mikado.

question: Where is Loch Lomond located?
tip: Loch Lomond is the largest expanse of fresh water in mainland Britain and probably the best-known part of the park. It is located in Scotland.

question: When is Halloween celebrated?
tip: Halloween, 31 October, is an ancient festival and has roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter. Young people will often dress up in frightening costumes to play ‘trick or treat’. People give them treats to stop them playing tricks on them. A lot of people carve lanterns out of pumpkins and put a candle inside.

question: Who defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo?
tip: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.

question: What percentage of the UK population is Sikh?
tip: In the 2009 Citizenship Survey, 1% of people identified themselves as Sikh.

question: Where are the most serious civil cases heard in England and Wales?
tip: More serious civil cases – for example, when a large amount of compensation is being claimed – are dealt with in the High Court in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

question: Who is responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence?
tip: Secretaries of State are responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence.

question: What did Henry VII do?
options: Increased the power of the nobles
Broke away from the Church of Rome
Reduced the power of the nobles
answers: Reduced the power of the nobles
tip: Henry VII wanted to make sure that England remained peaceful and that his position as king was secure. He deliberately strengthened the central administration of England and reduced the power of the nobles.

question: Which of these charities works with children?
tip: The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC) works with children.

question: Which of these are ‘Crown Dependencies’?
options: The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man
answers: The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man
tip: The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man are closely related to the UK but are not part of it. They have their own governments and are called ‘Crown dependencies’.

question: What is the capital of Wales?
tip: Cardiff is the capital of Wales.

question: Who sat in the House of Lords in the middle ages?
tip: The nobility, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords.

question: What is the official report that contains everything said in Parliament called?
tip: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard.

question: When did Ireland split into 2 countries?
tip: Ireland became two countries in 1922.

question: Where can you find the ship HMS Victory now?
tip: HMS Victory, can be visited in Portsmouth. It was Admiral Nelson’s ship.

question: For how long did England remain a republic?
tip: Britain had been a republic for 11 years.

question: What did the first farmers build in Britain?
tip: The first farmers built houses, tombs and monuments on the land.

question: What is the judiciary responsible for?
options: Deciding whether a person is guilty
tip: Judges, who are together called ‘the judiciary’, are responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that trials are conducted fairly.

question: When did the Enlightenment happen?
tip: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment’.

question: Who became one of the most popular monarchs in the 16th century?
tip: Queen Elizabeth I became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada.

question: Who developed important Human Nature ideas?
tip: David Hume’s ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers.

question: When did the WWI begin?
tip: The first World War began in 1914 and ended in 1918.

question: Where did the engineers come from in the middle ages?
tip: People came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Engineers came from Germany.

question: When is Boxing Day?
tip: Boxing Day (26th of December) is the day after Christmas Day (25th of December) and is a public holiday.

question: Who designed the new St Paul Cathedral?
tip: Christopher Wren designed a new St Paul Cathedral after the previous one was destroyed by a great fire in 1666.

question: Where was Florence Nightingale born?
tip: Florence Nightingale was born in Italy to English parents in 1820.

question: How often are the General Elections held?
tip: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years.

question: Where did the ancestors of the first farmers come from?
tip: The first farmers came to Britain 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe.

question: What is the fundamental principle of British life?
tip: The rule of law is one of the fundamental principles of British Life.

question: Which country’s flag is not part of the Union Flag?
tip: The Welsh dragon is not part of the Union Flag.

question: Which style of architecture became popular in the 19th century?
tip: In the 19th century, the medieval ‘gothic’ style became popular once again.

question: Which of these gardens is located in Wales?
tip: Bodnant Garden is in Wales.

question: Which countries are in Great Britain?
tip: Great Britain consists of 3 countries: England, Wales and Scotland.

question: Who is the head of the Church of England?
tip: The monarch is the head of the Church of England. The spiritual leader of the Church of England is the Archbishop of Canterbury.

question: What marked the beginning of “constitutional monarchy”?
tip: The laws passed after the Glorious Revolution are the beginning of what is called ‘constitutional monarchy’.

question: Who was one of the founders of England’s naval tradition?
tip: Sir Francis Drake, one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, was one of the founders of England’s naval tradition. His ship (The Golden Hind) was one of the first to sail around the world.

question: Under which king did the people unite to defeat the Vikings?
tip: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.

question: Who won two gold medals for running in the 2004 Olympic Games?
tip: Dame Kelly Holmes (1970–) won two gold medals for running in the 2004 Olympic Games.

question: When did the Roman army leave Britain?
tip: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned.

question: Which of these venues is located in Scotland?
tip: The Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre (SECC) is located in Glasgow, Scotland.

question: What percentage of the population has a grandparent born outside of the UK?
tip: Post-war immigration means that nearly 10% of the population has a parent or grandparent born outside the UK.

question: What proportion of the population died because of the Black Death?
tip: One third of the population of England and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales died because of the Black Death.

question: What language did the Iron Age people speak?
tip: Their language was part of the Celtic language family.

question: Who became Prime Minister during WWII?
tip: Hitler invaded Poland and took control of Belgium and the Netherlands. At this time of national crisis, Winston Churchill became Prime Minister.

question: What is the monarch’s ceremonial role?
tip: The Queen has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year.

question: When did people learn how to make bronze?
tip: Around 4,000 years ago, people learned to make bronze

question: Who mapped the coast of Australia?
tip: Captain James Cook mapped the coast of Australia.

question: What is the system that automatically deducts tax called?
tip: This system that deducts tax automatically is called ‘Pay As You Earn’, also known as PAYE.

question: What is the money limit for the small claims procedure in England and Wales?
tip: The small claims procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales.

question: Where in Scotland is known as the home of golf?
tip: St Andrews in Scotland is known as the home of golf.

question: What must the police officer tell you if you get arrested?
options: To put your arms in the air
tip: A Police officer will tell you the reason for your arrest and you will be able to seek legal advice.

tip: The Edinburgh Festival takes place in Edinburgh, Scotland, every summer. The most well-known is the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, also known as the Fringe.

question: What did the “Bill of Rights” confirm?
tip: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king’s power.

question: What do you need to apply for UK citizenship?

tip: To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to:

question: Hadrian’s Wall is a popular UNESCO World Heritage Site
tip: Parts of Hadrian’s Wall, including the forts of Housesteads and Vindolanda, can still be seen. It is a popular area for walkers and is a UNESCO (United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization) World Heritage Site.

question: Where did the people of the Bronze Age bury their dead?
tip: People lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs called round barrows.

question: What does the TV licence money pay for?
tip: The money from TV licences is used to pay for the British Broadcasting Corporation also known as the BBC.

question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
tip: World Wide Web was invented by Sir Tim Berners-Lee (1955–) who is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.

question: Who won gold medals in rowing in five consecutive Olympic Games?
tip: Sir Steve Redgrave won gold medals in rowing in five consecutive Olympic Games and is one of Britain’s greatest Olympians.

question: How old is Big Ben?
tip: Big Ben, also known as “Elizabeth Tower”, is over 150 years of age.

question: What was the population of the UK in 1901?
tip: The population of the UK was 40 million in 1901.

question: How long did the Romans stay in Britain?
tip: The Romans remained in Britain for 400 years.

question: Where does the Prime Minister reside?
tip: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street, in central London, near the Houses of Parliament.

question: Who was Henry Purcell?
tip: Henry Purcell (1659–95) was the organist at Westminster Abbey. He wrote church music and operas.

question: What is the Church of England known as in Scotland and the US?
tip: The official Church of the state is the Church of England is called the Episcopal Church in Scotland and the United States. It is a Protestant Church.

question: When do pubs usually open?
tip: Public Houses, also known as Pubs, usually open at 11:00 AM, 12:00 PM on Sundays.

question: What is known as Lent?
tip: The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent.
